block.p: Consumers have grown accustomed to buying books, records and more with the click of a mouse. But a home? On Oct. 1, the Electronic Signatures in Global Commerce Act went into effect, giving contracts signed by mouse, modem or other high-tech means the same legal weight as the ink-on-paper variety. The result could be increased convenience and cost savings for business and consumers alike, with the potential for increased security. The law, however, does not force consumers to sign on the dotted e-line. They can still opt for deals based on the paper variety. ''If you're not comfortable with closing a deal online, don't do it,'' advised Frank Torres, the legislative counsel at Consumers Union.
